title: Multiple Select Q23 Punctuation Multiple Select
prompt: Which two sentences are punctuated correctly?
feedback:
One sentence that is punctuated correctly is: “We can help you compare the available educational tools and find the product that best suits your needs.” The second part of the sentence (“find the product that best suits your needs”) is part of a compound predicate. The verb in this sentence is “compare and find.” There should not be any punctuation before the “and” in a compound predicate with two verbs like this one.

The other correctly punctuated sentence is: “They can greatly enhance the educational experience, but implementing this new technology can be challenging.” The conjunction “but” joins two complete independent clauses, so a comma is correct.

The sentence “Several large companies provide interactive whiteboards and most of these products use proprietary software” needs a comma before the “and,” since it joins two complete independent clauses.

The sentence “We would be happy to provide an estimate, for interactive whiteboards” has an unnecessary comma. No comma is needed before a prepositional phrase at the end of a sentence.

The sentence “Can you attend a meeting at our store on Monday June 3?” needs a comma between the day of the week and the date.

The sentence “Interactive whiteboards are very popular; but often schools don’t know how to integrate the technology into learning” should have a comma instead of a semicolon.
